com.yantra.api.wms.pickplanning

Interface releaseWave

  • All Known Subinterfaces:
    com.yantra.api.WMSApi, YIFApi

    public interface releaseWave

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      org.w3c.dom.Document releaseWave(YFSEnvironment env, org.w3c.dom.Document inXML)
      The releaseWave API releases the specified wave.

    • Method Detail

      • releaseWave

        org.w3c.dom.Document releaseWave(YFSEnvironment env,
                                 org.w3c.dom.Document inXML)
                          throws com.yantra.yfs.japi.YFSException,
                                 java.rmi.RemoteException
        The releaseWave API releases the specified wave. This is how algorithm works:

        Can wave be released
        Check if wave can be processed by this transaction. Following checks are performed to know if wave can be processed by this transaction.

          Status check: Wave should be in pickable status for this transaction. API invocation of the transaction throws error if status check fails, error WMS00159: Wave cannot be processed is thrown. Agent invocation ignores the error and deletes the task Q record for the transaction.

          Date check: Wave has ReleaseNoEarlierThan and ReleaseNoLaterThan dates that are computed during wave creation using wave release schedule. If OverrideReleaseDate (this attribute can be set using manageWave API) is set to 'Y' on the wave, then these dates are ignored and date checks are not performed. Otherwise dates should be such that ReleaseNoEarlierThan <= Current time <= ReleaseNoLaterThan. If the condition is not met, the error is thrown in case of API invocation. Error thrown: WMS00159: Wave cannot be processed. In case of agent invocation, these dates are re-computed using release wave schedule and if the new dates satisfy the condition then wave is set to release immediately. Otherwise these dates are updated on the wave and task Q record is updated with 'ReleaseNoEarlierThan' date.

          Number of wave released concurrently: This is the property of a shipment group. If this is set (not 0!) then this check is performed. API invocation throws error if the check fails. Error thrown WMS00174 : Wave cannot be released as number of concurrent released waves will be exceeded. Agent invocation updates the task Q record with next available date.


        Pick process determination
        The following steps are followed to determine pick process for an Item:

        1. ShipmentLines for same Item are grouped together.
        2. All the eligible uoms for the Item are obtained by applying Buyer Compliance and Overpack constraints.
        3. Pick Process is determined for each Item Uom in the descending order of Item Uom Quantity.
          Pick Processes are evaluated in the order -
          1.Item Picking
          2.Order Picking
          3.Batch Picking
          - all the eligible Pick Processes are selected and processed until demand is satisfied.

          Multiple Pick Processes can be eligible for same Uom. For example if Item Picking and Order Picking can be performed then Item Picking is processed first for the full demand.If demand could not be satisfied completely, then for the remaining demand Order Picking is processed.

          Note: Item Picking - If ItemPick process is selected for an Item Uom, then all the PLA Uom Conditions defined are exhausted to satisfy the demand. Hence Item Pick Process will not be repeated for more than one Item Uom, as all the Uom Conditions would have been already processed by then.
          Order Picking/Batch Picking - In case of Order Picking and Batch Picking only the PLA Uom Condition corresponding to the Item Uom processed is chosen to satisfy the demand.

        4. The above process is repeated for all the Item Uoms until demand is completely satisfied or all the uoms are exhausted.


        Pick location assignment
        This is the core of wave release. This is called for each item-uom combination. These are following sub steps.

        • Determine source zone sets. Source zone sets are configured at item-uom level with a certain priority assigned to each of these sets. Inventory is searched in each zone set till the demand quantity is satisfied.

          • Onhand Inventory: First locations having inventory in the zones specified is looked at.
          • Dedicated Locations: If sufficient inventory is not found in the zones specified then look for over allocation. First attempt is to over allocate the dedicated locations if allowed. If allowed, following rules are applied while looking for dedicated locations that can be over allocated.
          • Dedicated locations can be over allocated only from one zone. First step is to find the best zone, which has dedicated locations that can hold the demand. If no such zone is found then take a zone, which has maximum capacity available to dedicated locations. Distribute the demand in order of capacity available in dedicated locations. Over stuff the first location found.
          • Dynamic Locations: For the remaining demand, dynamic slotting is performed if allowed. Find locations in the zones specified that can hold the demand. In case of dynamic slotting, mixing of SKUs on a location is not allowed.
            • However, mixing of inventory attributes like ship-by-date,country Of Origin,segment,segment type and fifo number for the same sku is allowed irrespective of the zone-level mixing constraints for these attributes.
          • Pickfence Locations: Whenever a dedicated location has demand that pickfence factor times capacity, demand is removed from dedicated location and dynamic slotted to a pickfence location.
          • Cross dock Locations: Cross dock opportunities are explored for the remaining demand. Search for inbound shipments in the statuses configured. If a shipment is found with same item as requested then demand can be satisfied against the found inbound shipment. To allocate against the shipment, dynamic slot locations in the zones mentioned. Maximum demnd that can be cross-docked is min (capacities of dynamic locations found, quantity available for cross dock).


        • Pick location assignment for over-allocated quantity
          This step is performed for any over allocated quantity.Step Pick location assignment is read for activity group 'REPLENISHMENT'. Any quantity allocation that cannot be replenished will be removed.


        • Work order handling
          If there is not sufficient inventory to fulfill the shipment lines released in a wave, the system checks if any of the shipment lines are for segmented inventory. If there are shipment lines for segmented inventory, the system then checks to see if there have been any work orders that have been released that may fulfill the required quantity upon completion. In cases when no applicable work orders have been released, the system looks for one or more work orders that will create the least available quantity while still fulfilling the quantity of the shipment line.


        • Pick task creation
          Pick tasks are created for each pick from a location. Task type is determined for each zone set. For each task created, location inventory is updated.


        • Exception Handling
          By this step, all the options are explored.
          The Exception List is optimized by re-allocating the pickable quantity between the shipment lines in the Exception List, so that a minimum number of shipment lines in Exception List are achieved. Again here if the Zone constraint doesn't allow the pickable quantity to split for a particular shipment, then those lines will not be considered for optimization.
          If there is still unfulfilled quantity then the shipment lines having shortages are handled based on how the property yfs.releaseWave.handleShortages has been defined in yfs.properties file.
          If yfs.releaseWave.handleShortages=RemoveShipmentsFromWave, even if one line has inventory shortage, the whole shipment will be removed from the wave.
          If yfs.releaseWave.handleShortages=RemoveShipmentLinesFromWave, the shipment lines having inventory shortages, will be removed from the wave and separate child shipments will be created for these lines.
          If yfs.releaseWave.handleShortages=RemoveShortageQuantitiesFromWave, wave will be released with available inventory and child shipments would be created for shortage quantities.
          However, depending upon the zone constraints, the PLA Configuration, and the Replenishment Strategy, the Handle Shortages options, 'RemoveShortageQuantitiesFromWave' and 'RemoveShortageShipmentLines', may not fully allocate the available inventory to the shipments although theoretically it is possible to do so.


        • Create and Release of Move request
          If there is any over allocated quantity then move request is created with 'Release' option.


        • Status update
          If all the shipment lines are removed from the wave then wave goes to 'Canceled (9000)' status otherwise wave status is moved to 'Released (1300)'.

        Related Documents
        Input XML Input DTD Output XML Output DTD Error XML Error DTD

        User Exits: This API invokes the following user exit:

          *
          YCPBeforeCreateTaskUE

        Events Raised:

        ON_SUCCESS:
        Data published - WMS_RELEASE_WAVE.ON_SUCCESS.xml
        Key data - wave_dbd.txt

        Template Support: Yes

        Configuration Required for backward compatibility: No


        SHORTAGES_DETECTED: This event is raised when shipment is removed from wave due to not having sufficient inventory.
        Data published - WMS_RELEASE_WAVE.SHORTAGES_DETECTED.xml
        Key data - wave_dbd.txt

        Template Support: Yes

        Configuration Required for backward compatibility: No

        Audits: None

        Pre-conditions: None

        Post-conditions: None

        Output Template Support: Yes

        Database Extensibility Support: No

        Configuration Required for Backward Compatibility: No

        Parameters:
        env - Required. Environment handle returned by the createEnvironment API.
        inXML - Required. For more information, see the associated input xml files.

        Returns:
        An XML document that contains wave details. For details on the output, refer to the associated output files.
        Throws:
        com.yantra.yfs.japi.YFSException - Exception containing error codes in the standard error files.
        java.rmi.RemoteException - Java's default remote exception handler.
